Dear Ms. Shenberger:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 7/7/2025. A exit conference was held with the agency on 7/8/2025. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12202 Policy and procedures.
(1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
procedures for all the areas of foster care services as
provided in R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
The agency requires its employees to complete annual ICHATs and central
registry clearances. One of nine employee records reviewed where the employee
had been employed for over one year did not show documentation of the said
clearance due by 2/19/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(2) The personnel record must contain all the following
information before employment may occur:
(h) Documentation from the department that the person
has not been named in a central registry case as the
perpetrator of child abuse or neglect in Michigan or in
any state where the person lived in the 5 years
preceding hire.
One of six new employee records reviewed did not show documentation of an out
of state central registry clearance. The respective employee hired 12/4/2024 had

resided in New York state; and the clearance was obtained on 7/3/2025, after my
review of this record.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 5/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record must contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's
performance within a probationary period or not later
than 6 months after the staff member assumes his or
her current responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a
written evaluation must be conducted every 12 months.
One of fifteen employee records reviewed showed the employee's probationary
evaluation was due by 3/4/2025 and completed late on 4/17/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP Approved 2/13/2025.
Interim 2023, CAP Approved 5/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation of all relevant parties,
including the child or infant, which includes an
explanation as to why the change is necessary.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child was replaced
three times and the record did not show documentation of preparation for the
change for the child and all parties with respect to each replacement.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:

(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed, the record did not show
verification that the information was provided to the caregiver in two of three of
the child's replacements.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must,
include all the following:
(f) A dental re-examination must be obtained at least
every 9 months, unless a greater frequency is
indicated.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed the record showed the child's
dental was due by 5/16/2025 and completed late on 6/17/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 5/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child
placing agency to another child placing agency, a
modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if
no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan must
address why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
In one of eight open foster child records reviewed a 30-day report which was due
by 3/5/2025 was not documented.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents
and the foster parents in the development of service
plans to enable the parent or parents and foster
parents to understand the plan for the child and the

parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a
copy to and review the parent-agency treatment plan
with the parent or parents and foster parents. The
agency must inform the parent or parents and foster
parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
In four of eight open foster child records reviewed the respective child’s record did
not show that all treatments plans were reviewed and signed timely by all parties.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, cited under FOM 722-8D, CAP approved 2/13/2025.
Interim 2023, cited under FOM 722-8D, CAP approved 5/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be
used by the foster parents.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
the specific behavior management support plan to be used by the caregiver in the
last three updated service plans (UPS) for one child; last two USPs for the
second child; or the last USP with respective the last two child cases.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 2/13/2025.
Interim 2023, CAP Approved 5/8/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be
documented in the youth's record.

In one of six open independent living youth records reviewed the record showed
the youth’s medical was due by 5/7/2025; and it was completed late on
5/21/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 2/13/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Five of six adoptive family records reviewed did not show that the family's written
adoptive evaluation was completed with 90 days of the respective family’s
adoption application date.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 2/14/2025.
CPA Rule 400.12607 Agency recommendation.
(4) An agency shall provide the applicants for adoption
with a signed and dated copy of the evaluation and
recommendation upon its completion.
One of six open adoptive family records reviewed did not show documentation
that the family was provided a copy of the adoptive evaluation upon its
completion.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 5/8/2024.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• R400.12327(3) Special evaluation: The agency was apprised that it shall more
clearly document that the chief administrator or his or her designee has given
written approval for extending the special investigation beyond 90 days.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care: The agency was
advised obtaining the youth's signed refusal for health services prior to the
youth's medical/dental examination due date may aid it in compliance with
this rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans during this
licensing period. The first corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024
Renewal inspection where it received 22 rule violations, of which 14 were repeat
violations and that inspection resulted in the agency’s license being modified to a
second provisional license. During this 2025 Renewal inspection 12 rule violation
were established. Eight of the 12 violations are repeat violations; 5 are repeats
from 2024 and 6 repeats from 2023. The agency’s corrective action plan
compliance around the 8 is as follows: the number of individual cases cited
decreased in all except for 2 rule violations, where the number of individual cases
cited increased from 2 of 8 to 4 of 8 for one rule; and from 1 of 1 to 5 of 6 related
to the other rule violation.
It is noted that the agency has implemented this corrective action plan and has
made significant improvements related to rule compliance and staffing issues.
The agency continues to work with staff around policy and rule understanding and
improving compliance.
The second corrective action plan related to Special Investigation
2024SIC0000001 where the intake was received on 10/1/2024. The complaint
alleged that the director advised a supervisor to falsify information related to
sibling contacts and that the director was not following the treatment foster care
contract. During the investigation the agency was found in violation of Act 116-
722.120(C) related to providing accurate and truth information to the department.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan that was approved on
3/27/2025. The agency has since completed that corrective action plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 6/20/2025. The chief
administrator (CA) reported on the prior year's violation and the steps it put in
place to achieve compliance, as well as indicated systematic factors that impacted

compliance. Those factors included the length of time from employee separation
to hiring and training a new staff; abrupt resignation and termination of staff and
how that results in the agency hiring and training cycle already being behind.
Additionally health insurance impacting timely medical and dental exams due to
sometimes having to switch a primarily care provider for the child and at times an
inability to get an appointment for the child prior to the needed exams due date,
independent living youths not cooperating with staff on ensuring completion of
their medicals and dentals, and MISACWIS not factoring in a youth's medical
refusal form completions.
The CA indicated the agency did not accept very many cases during this
inspection period due to staff turnover and an increased focus on caseload
compliance. Additionally, the CAP still has been successful with medical and
dental completions with email reminders occurring; and that parent agency
treatment plan agreements are better tracked during monthly supervisions.
Strengths the CA listed for the agency were that it has increased oversight on
caseload compliance; increased timeliness and completion of onboarding training;
and has increased completion of annual evaluations. The areas of focus listed
was developing a 6-month check-in with new staff; and continuing to assess what
will be beneficial action steps around medical and dental completions; and parent
agency treatment plan agreements.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a copy of its 2025 annual budget; and September 2024,
2024, independent financial audit. A review of this document did not show any
areas of concern.
Staff and Youth Interviews
In addition to my discussion with the chief administrator, foster care/adoption
program manager, licensing supervisor, independent living program manager and
independent living supervisor, and a foster care supervisor, I interviewed two
foster care workers and an adoption worker. Strengths reported included flexibility
related to being able to work onsite after 5:00pm; support from the management
team and coworkers; and the agency’s awareness of it past mistakes and
willingness to make corrections. Areas of concerns listed included a belief that
some staff favoritism exists, receiving more individual appreciation and
verbalization on how one is doing in their role. Also, the desire for the
development of a master list of all report due dates (service plans, court reports,
medicals, dentals, etc.) monthly and for that list to be circulated to all staff to help
everyone know what is coming due and to aid in monitoring.
Description of Agency Walk Through
During a walkthrough of the facility no concerns were revealed. The agency’s
records are securely stored, and there appears to be sufficient equipment for staff.

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one identified safety alert.
Safety Alert: No operable smoke detectors on each level of occupancy and or near
all sleeping areas. The smoke detector on the upper level was beeping. The smoke
detector in the basement was beeping.
Resolution: On 5/2/2025 an agency worker visited the caregiver's home, another
smoke detector was provided to the family and installed where one was missing.
The family bought and installed batteries in the two smoke detectors that were
beeping. The worker verified the working order of the smoke detectors and provided
photos of the detectors.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
